Nothing is that easy.  Meaning: he won't pay. He opens the shutters, stares out at the rain. We study his face. Cheekbones rising, nostrils flaring sl Something is happening to him. Europe is carefully drawn but dispropor tionately large and central. Africa is sketched huge, vague. South America does not exist at all. Men load a ship. Some plain and rough, some gentry; even are tough, self-made men, rather than limp aristocrats. Cortes' banner flies high over a line of recruiting table the dock. We move down the line:

(charming grin) I want a cauldron full of gold.
.a business venture! If you contribute money, a musket, a horse, then you get extra Shares.
I wrote to your father, not you! You're too young! He's addressing Gonzalo de SANDOVAL, whose enthusiasm, in slight stammer make him very likeable and somewhat comic.
I'm t-t-twenty-two!

I haven't had a pimple in years. Find me a place or I will stow with the rats!  7. As Sandoval steps aside, the Third Interviewer (JUAN VELA LEON, 27) mutters something to Cortes about the applicant interviewing: PEDRO DE ALVARADO, 34, a golden boy with lo a massive physique, a gold chain, and sublime confidence.

Isn't trouble what we're looking for? I'm stronger than any man in your army, and happier, I can wiggle my ears, and I can pulla horse down with one hand. Cortes stares at him. But his stare is interrupted by a t squawking from the other end of the dock. Cortes glances turns back to Alvarado:

Step over there. Alvarado saunters to one side as the commotion moves towa CRISTOBAL DE OLID, protesting loudly, is being dragged by Olid is so strong he could toss the others into the drink sense he's actually coming of his own free will.
Senor Cristobal! So nice of you to visit. How are your headaches?
Try to make me join, I'll kill you.
No, no, you misunderstand. I brought you here for a contest of strength.
Don't bore me.

(motions: see?) | Please. Teach him some humility.

You're walking from a challenge? Cristobal blinks, stalks to Alvarado, holds out his right confidence that is electrifying: no way he can lose.  8. How many minutes? Diero is heading toward them, accompanied by armed SOLDIE Puertocarrero makes for the boats, starts shouting orders The contest of strength continues: so equal it's comic. The Second Page unmuzzles and releases a MASTIFF, which r the men, barking fiercely, leaping up on them - Cristobal curses, flails at the dog with his free arm, wh Alvarado to throw Cristobal to the deck. (to Cristobal) It's true, then. He is stronger? (to Diero) One minute.
That miserable cur almost bit me! I demand a proper contest!
We're sailing. Only way to get satisfaction is to come along. Cristobal glares. Cortes takes him aside, ignoring Diero'
I'll give you a quarter of my profits.
What profit? You're going to die.
Then do it out of friendship.
I never liked you. Cortes rolls his eyes. Clearly they have a friendship, bu is professionally grumpy -
For glory then?
Whose? You'll get it all.
(clutching at straws) We: hear the native women. three hours with one of them is worth a five year affair here in Cuba. And you can take as many as you want.
A hundred? Cortes does a slight double-take, quickly recovers:
Two hundred, or more... Cristobal nods soberly. Certainly a factor worth consider
Cortes! As mayor of this town and emissary of the governor, I demand -
What is it, my friend?
You are under arrest. If you do not go quietly, my soldiers will fire. The Soldiers aim their muskets at Cortes.
What am I charged with?

Treason. Plotting to exceed your authority and conquer the Indians. Both men look up at Cortes' BANNER, which reads: "Comrade the sign of the cross and through it we shall conquer." Cortes stares at the muskets. He doesn't seem to have muc holds out his hands to be manacled, and for a moment it s story will be over before it begins.  10.
Looking back, I have often wondered how many men, in Cortes' place, would even have made it out of port? As the Soldiers move to shackle Cortes, he says loudly:
But I must caution you. These men already feel loyalty to me. I can't be responsible for what they might do to your town, or your person -
(outraged) You are inciting them to -

(quiet confidence) No. If I incite them, you'll know it. (as Diero hesitates) We sail in ten minutes. (giving him his excuse ) What a pity you didn't get here in time to stop us. Diero nods. He will accept this ploy.
You cowardly sack of slime. (as Diero bridles) Just a figure of speech. (embracing him, whispers: ) Don't forget your 50%!
You will regret that insult.
No. I'll either dine with trumpets or die on the gallows, but I'l regret nothing. Cortes heads toward his ship, Puertocarrero at his side. of the ship: a_ huge pile of crucifixes of varying sizes.
How short are we?
Fifty men and half our supplies.
We'll stop in Havana. He notices Sandoval climbing aboard ship -  11.
Hey! Kid! Sandoval winces: he got caught.
Can you look a man in the eye and lie?
I can learn.
How old are you? Sandoval looks Cortes straight in the eye:
T-t-t-twenty-five.
(playful) Jesus. That is awful. He motions for Sandoval to jump on board. As they do -

It is only 150 miles from Cuba to the coast of the Yucatan. None of us had any idea the true distance we were travelling. Cortes pauses, looks at BOTELLO, a small exotic man nervo examining tarot cards and dispensing gloom to three Deckh Puertocarrero comes up to Cortes and nods: the men are re climbs to the topdeck and peers out: posture of a great l voice echoes in the fog:

My friends, my partners. Tomorrow we land. Tomorrow we place our lives and fortunes in the hands of God, for we know not where we go, who we meet, what horrors we encounter, if there will be men or arms or beasts far stronger, more numerous, and more terrifying than our own... (MORE)

The men cheer wildly.
Few in number, but strong in arm, ...and will... and resolution. Stronger still in the love of God. With His Grace may we go. In His Name may we survive... (peers out at fog) the unknown.

The Yucatan was so named because the first Spaniards who landed asked the name of the country, and the natives answered, "Tectetan," meaning, "I do not understand you." The CAMERA moves out of camp, into the dense brush. A LON Motionless. Watching the Spaniards...

We knew from the two previous expeditions that the natives had never seen horses before. The Indians gape in consternation but stand their ground horses, only yards away, are reined in so that they raise legs in an apparent attack posture - The Indians flee in terror...  18.
They thought these beasts were centaurs, magical creatures: half- men, half-hornless deer. As the cavalry gives chase, the Indians vanish into the w

text: An Indian procession. Porters bringing food, followed by BEAUTIFUL NATIVE GIRLS (nine naked to the waist), and las CHIEFS. In the center, supported by several men because h large to walk, is the FAT CACIQUE, their leader.  19.

As Cortes requested, food came... and other gifts. But these Indians were not the ones we'd been fighting. Instead, they came from Cempoala. We were learning that, as in ancient Greece, the land here was divided not into countries, but into city- states. As the half-naked girls approach, the Spaniards - Cristob especially - stare with undisguised lust...
I like the one in green. Cristobal sticks out his hand: arm-wrestle?
No, no, you're champion now. You pick first.

(nods, stares) Actually, I like them all. The Fat Cacique arrives in front of Cortes, dismounts fro with some difficulty, and attempts to bow. Cortes stifles a smile and bows back LATER. Nine Indian Girls are being baptized by Father Olmeda as Captains look on, admiring the girls' breasts...
I trust no man casts a lascivious eye on a religious ceremony...
The contrary. We are filled with awe at what the Lord has created. Velasquez De Leon approaches, preceded by the tallest and beautiful of the Native Girls, MARINA, still fully clothe
Captain, this one speaks Spanish. as Cortes looks her over) She claims to have been a princess.
What's your name?
Malinali Tenepal. You will call me Marina.  20.
I will, eh? How did you learn Spanish?
When my father died, my mother the Queen sold me as a Slave to favor the children of her second husband. Another slave, with me, was a Spaniard.
From which expedition? She shrugs.
Where is this Spaniard now?
Gone. (i.e., dead)
He was your lover, then?
(flat) No. Cortes stares at her. She stares back. A pride both admir infuriating...
So...your own family, your own mother, betrayed you.
She betrayed herself. He stifles a smile of appreciation.

Since you are a princess and deserve the best, I give you... (looks over his men, seems to focus on Alvarado) to my good friend...Puertocarrero. Puertocarrero steps forward, blinking, shy but quite plea shoots him the briefest glance.

However, you will be on call day and night as my translator. Conch shell trumpets sound.  21. A cortege of ornately dressed INDIANS approaches. The rest of his tribe precedes him. In seconds, they are glances at Marina, then at the approaching Indians -
Aztecs. They have conquered most of these towns from a city, Mexico, high in the mountains.
Mexico? Where the gold is?
They call it "excrement of the Gods."
Then you - you're not an Aztec?
Never. The Mexicans conquered m city, They rule harshly, throug ear. Her eyes dart toward the woods where the Cempoalans are h Cortes follows her gaze.

Good. She shoots him a glance. Why "good?" The AZTECS arrive. Their simple cloaks and sandals evoke the Ancient Greeks. On the other hand, their ears, lips, and noses are garnis pendants formed of precious stones. SERVANTS cloud the air with copal incense, others display THREE PRINCES touch the ground, then their heads, in gree speak alternately, diffusing their identity.
They come from the great Lord Moctezuma who sends these gifts as a token of friendship. They say his capital is too far to travel to, and the road beset with too many enemies...

Good God.  22. The Servants have set out two magnificent circular plates silver, the other gold, both as large as carriage wheels. plate represents the moon, the gold one the sun. Both are wrought with calendar signs and images of Gods. Cortes' young PAGE (who, through dress and manner, sugges coming of the modern mercantile age) steps forward to rec
The gold plate alone is worth 20,000 pesos and the workmanship surpasses anything in Europe.
These bribes whet my appetite.
We Indians say: the greater the gift, the greater the King.

Tell them I too come from a powerful King who orders me to pay personal respects to Lord Moctezuma, of whose greatness he has long heard tell. As I have had a difficult journey over the sea, I dare not return home without seeing Moctezuma face to face.
King Carlos doesn't know - Cortes silences him with a look - One of the Aztec Princes replies testily:
"You hardly arrive and you insist on seeing on our Emperor's face?" One Prince points at something, and the others jabber exc Cortes watches this, then glances inquiringly at Marina.
They call you "Teules." Gods. Or perhaps those sent by the Gods...
Cortes nods thoughtfully...

They may take this helmet to show the great Moctezuma. В«providing they return it filled with gold. we Spanish suffer a disease of the heart which can only be cured by gold. He gestures, and four horses approach, their bells jingli The Aztecs stand, mouths agape, watching the horses. An Aztec scribe quickly paints the horses onto bark paper already sketched Cortes, Marina, and the Spanish ships.
Walking together.
The helmet, horses. Is that why they call us Gods?
Your looks, ships, clothing - it's all strange to them. You are not like men. So what are you?
(nods, answers: ) Gods. Which ones?

They mentioned the great Teule Quetzalcoatl. 500 years ago he sailed to the East, promising to return. He had light hair, like some of your men. Perhaps you are him. Perhaps King Carlos is. Perhaps this, your coming, fulfills an ancient prophecy. (as Cortes thinks) You must know: to the Aztec, prophecy is law. It is even the same word. We see a thousand calculations race through Cortes' mind.
You say the Aztecs rule, but the other cities hate and fear them?
Yes.
Then we can win.  24. They've reached the woods where the Fat Cacique and the o Cempoalans are hiding.

...that our will, of which he spoke with such pride, was already weakening.

Do you leave the table if the appetizer is savory?

And - most important - we have done our duty and completed our mission. Anything more would be mutiny. Cortes stares at him.
You're right. Of course. We sail in the morning. Cristobal grins, de Leon is taken aback.

Even so - She puts her fingers to his lips, silencing him.

Tell yourself this: Once I was a princess. Now, at your side, I ama queen. Malinche. They even call yu by my name. What more could I ask? He nods his understanding. But her expression betrays mor the truth is, she does everything because of him.

Cortes sits on his horse. Marina and Father Olmeda stand They are surrounded by the Spanish Army. 3000 Cholulans pack the square, including Papas, Caciques Cortes gestures to his Page, who bangs a large atabel.  55. Silence. His words fill it. Marina simultaneously transla

You have fed us, pampered us, and freely given us...your whores. A second screen closes a second entrance. Horsemen with s their places in front of the screen. CORTES (CONT' Dy We know that you are allies of Moctezuma, that you must take orders from him, and that sometimes those orders run contrary to your wishes and your own sweet nature. For example, we know he has sent an army, now on the outskirts of your city, which plans to attack us with your help. The Cholulans look around in confusion and alarm. Why is this? How does he know it? Why is his tone so mild? The screen for the fourth and last entrance to the square TwO SOLDIERS try vainly to put it into place as:

And we know you have given help. You have put stakes in the street, stacked rocks on the roofs of your houses, evacuated women and children, and you intended to slaughter us, even though we are your guests. Cortes looks at the last entrance: still open. He waits. Anxious silence.

I know all this, because I know everything. The Cholulans stand in fear and in awe: this man is surel  56. Forget the screen. A dozen soldiers move to fill the last When Cortes sees this is accomplished:

Sadly, you leave us little choice. We are going to kill you now, all of you, in rightful punishment. The Cholulans contemplate their imminent death... Beat. Cortes nods. Gunfire, screams, shouts...but we see only Cortes. A drop flies onto his armor. Then another. MORE. He's getting spattered. As the sounds of the massacre become intolerable, they fa Two drops hit Cortes' face, and he closes his eyes. Seren face...or perhaps denial. A long silent beat...

Whatever else you say the strategic value of this massacre was enormous. Again we appeared to have read the native mind, and we displayed a wrath so awesome it seemed Godlike. Without opening his eyes, Cortes turns toward Father Olme
If we can convert _one more Indian, save one more soul from damnation, then this will have been - (justified)  57.

Does Moctezuma think I'm stupid? (beat, re: the Prince) What's he selling me now? The Aztec Prince is indicating that the left fork is pref Cortes smiles politely to the Prince and proceeds down th the right. As they go:
(to Aztec Prince) You must tell me, since you are a noble lord, what the Great Moctezuma is like. The Aztec Prince replies: MARINA ; "I have never seen his face."
The army slogs along a windy mountain trail. Ahh for the home fire...  58.

Remember now the furor Columbus' discoveries had caused throughout the civilized world... Though we were on this bleak trail for many reasons - to grow rich, to grow famous, to die young - still there was one desire which touched us all. We wanted to look over the mountain. We wanted to see the exotic new world. Behind Cortes, Marina is riding beside Sandoval. Her mann formal, reserved. She simply wants the information:
Can you tell me something?
I will try.
I know the love some mothers feel for their children, but what is this other love you Spaniards speak of?
Between a man and w-woman?

(the expert) More than that. It is pure.
Like love of your God?
No, no. It makes you feel kind of crazy and weak and -

Not at all. It's just... Well: You know it when you have it! (beat ) Do you l-love Cortes?! Beat.
Please try again later, to explain.  59. They're cresting a hill. Cortes turns back toward them an

Cortes whirls - The Valley of Mexico stretched below them: A spectacular city filled with huge stone buildings, buil water, connected to land by long causeways. It seems like enchanted vision. "I do not know how to describe this fir of things never heard of, seen, or dreamed of before." Th magical realm, a kingdom from our fantasies. The faces of the Spaniards are filled with awe. Over the center of the city, one large bird-of-prey cuts in the azure sky...

The Army moving along one of the dikes. Every structure - houses, towers, pyramids - is crowded w Likewise the lakes are darkened by swarms of canoes fille Indians straining for a glimpse of these pale, outlandish strangers. The welcome is powerful and eerie. Not warm, not triumpha certainly not cold and antagonistic. It is wary. The inex native faces heighten the feeling that we have entered an universe. Floating on the lake are fairy islands of flowers. These islands undulate as the water rises and falls. The causeway itself is only nine yards wide, crowded with and broken occasionally by bridges. One of Xicotencatl's Sons, at Cortes' side, points to a b
"These are easily removed. Soon we will be trapped inside their city."  60.

(nods) They must wonder why we look so confident. In the distance, the royal palanquin, blazing with burnis approaches. It is borne by nobles and bears a canopy of g work, powdered with jewels and fringed with silver. Cortes descends from his horse. He puts on his helmet, topped with a plume of feathers. The canopied bier stops and slowly MOCTEZUMA descends. Though we saw him at the opening of the film, in darkness glimpse did not prepare us for the spectacle we now witne He is magnificently clad, in a turquoise robe studded wit jewels, gold sandals, and spectacular feathered headdress strew the ground with cotton tapestry, so his imperial fe touch the soil. Everyone around him except the most prominent nobles has lowered: they cannot look at the "Great Speaker." On either side of Moctezuma are princes: CUITLAHUA and CU The CAMERA FOCUSES on one, then the other:

Two great Princes flanked Moctezuma. His brother, Cuitlahua, had sworn to be our enemy and would have caused great harm had he not died of smallpox brought by one of our soldiers. The Emperor's nephew, Cuauhtemoc, vowed he would achieve our extinction. For most of us, he kept his word. Cuauhtemoc, only 25, has about him a sense of assurance a usually reserved for those of far greater age. His featur delicate, and very grave. Moctezuma himself is 40 years old, handsome, tall. His ha and straight, his beard thin, his complexion rather light with dignity, and there is great intelligence in his eyes

Moctezuma had ruled for 17 years. Once the fiercest of warriors, he was now a deeply religious man. He knew, from his reports and his oracles, that one way or another we were to be his fate. The two leaders stare at each other. They bow.  61. There is a long and magnificent silence. This moment - th two such sophisticated, and yet wildly different, civiliz unique in human history. Both sides simply stare in wonde Finally the frozen moment is broken as the Princes around with seeming reluctance, touch the ground, then bring the their chests and heads.

Their hearts and minds welcomed us. Cortes takes out a necklace of glass beads and puts it ar Moctezuma's neck. It looks crude and plain next to the Az Then Cortes starts to embrace Moctezuma, but the other Az rush forward and stop him. Cortes nods and steps back. Moctezuma speaks. Marina begins to translate. Toward the speech her voice FADES SOFTER as simultaneous SUBTITLES c Eventually her voice stops altogether, though her physica tells us she is still translating.

O Lord, our Lord, you have arrived in this land, your land, your own city of Mexico, to sit on your mat your stool, which I have guarded for you. Your vassals, the old kings, my ancestors, are gone. Would that one of them could rise from the dead astonished and see what my eyes truly see, for in no dream do I see your face. Ah, these days, five, ten, a string of days, I have been anxious, watching for you, waiting to see you appear from your hidden place among the clouds and mists. For I was told you would appear, you would return to sit on your mat, your stool, and it is come true. Welcome and rest. Rest now. Rest in your palace. With your lords and companions, take your rest. Moctezuma grasps Cuitlahua's hand, turns and walks toward Cuauhtemoc takes Cortes' hand, and they follow. Cuauhtemoc is seething. Marina walks at Cortes' side:
Moctezuma's greeting is warm. The Great Speaker seems to see you as the fulfillment of the ancient prophecy, the return of the Quetzalcoatl.
And the others?  62.
They are more...cautious. Cortes glances at the angry Cuauhtemoc.

That's an understatement. The CAMERA RISES slightly so that we see how small the Sp looks compared to the Indian population, and the magnific city. As the Spaniards file past, Cristobal, ever paranoid, say Alvarado:
God help us to leave here alive.
In the shadow of a giant PYRAMID (or cue), Moctezuma gest Cortes, indicating his own spectacular palace of silicate alabaster, surrounded by ponds and gardens.
This is his palace. We are to stay in the palace of his father. He leads the Spanish procession into the building next do
The ceilings are carved cedar, the walls hung with cotton tapestries. Moctezuma leads Cortes by the hand into a
A cotton mat ornamented with gold and jewels is draped ov Moctezuma gestures for Cortes to sit.

Your old mat, your familiar stool. Cortes sits. Moctezuma nods in quiet contentment. The attitude of the other Aztecs tells us: they have neve seen anyone sit there. Moctezuma gestures and PORTERS enter bearing trays of foo
With hostile civility, Cuauhtemoc leads Cortes and his hi through gardens which are far less formal, but no less be than the French gardens Louis XIV would create 175 years

The next day Moctezuma's nephew, Cuauhtemoc, gave us a tour of Aztec wonders. At first we thought it an act of hospitality. Fruit trees. Borders of trellises supporting aromatic shrubs and creep Riotous washes of pink and purple and lavender; subtle sh delight the eye and nourish the soul. Fields of exotic', orchids: not hot-house creations but h flowers dancing gaudily into the distance. Cuauhtemoc does not speak, and there is no need. The magi reality washes over us. Cardinals, quetzales, endless species of parrots, humming Cuauhtemoc is completely at home: as if he too were a bir Marina (present, as always, whenever we see Moctezuma or Aztecs) seems to share this sense of peace. The Spaniards Cortes is restless, looking around... He squints. Points
What's that there? Cuauhtemoc does not even glance where Cortes is pointing. Moctezuma, his words are SUBTITLED.
A golden eagle. The GOLDEN EAGLE has an individual perch high over the ot
Why is it kept separate?
Our city was built here because my ancestors saw an omen on the lake: a_golden eagle with a serpent in its talons, its wings spread wide to the rising sun.
Cuauhtemoc walks on, as if he wants to change the subject this, Cortes lingers:
A magnificent bird.
We see fewer and fewer alive.

Pumas, ocelots, alligators, etc. When we Gacrifice our enemies, we feed the torsos to these beasts. A casual and gracefully delivered threat. Cortes nods and follows Cuauhtemoc toward the: SNAKE CAGES. Various vipers, moccasins, coral snakes... Cuauhtemoc watches keenly for Cortes' reaction.
I don't like snakes. Marina does not translate this. Cortes looks at her.
The God Quetzalcoatl, in spirit form, is half-bird, half-snake. Cortes looks into a cage with two RATTLESNAKES.
Open the cage. Marina translates. Cuauhtemoc orders it, and the cage is opened. Cortes enters. One of the snakes is asleep, the other looks at him waril
The most dangerous of vipers. Cortes takes a step forward.  65. The snake starts to rattle.

This noise is a warning - Cortes freezes. Not a muscle twitching. The snake moves its head side to side, watching him... Cuauhtemoc observing... Cortes' immobility calms the snake. Then Cortes moves. Perversity? The snake rattles furiously - Cortes throws his handkerchief - The snake strikes - At the handkerchief. Cortes strolls calmly out of the cage. Cuauhtemoc looks back and forth between Cortes and the sn quite sure what he's just witnessed...
Huge buildings on every side. The tour has stopped beside round stone covered with markings.

Even now, 50 years later, this stone crammed with symbols of knives, houses, and rabbits, is the most accurate calendar on earth. They walk forward, toward the giant pyramid. He says there are 136,000 skulls. AS many as 50,000 have been sacrificed in a single year. The Spaniards stand transfixed with horror.  66. Cuauhtemoc gestures and they begin to climb the cue. Cuau below, staring after them with undisguised contempt. Moct for the Spaniards at the top.

We realized: this tour had been a warning. If we were not Gods, we should know we were dealing with an advanced - and lethal - civilization. As they climb the cue, something is thrown off the top. Down below, butchers carve the bodies. Arms and legs are served to warriors, the rest to the lions. Cortes shoots a glance at Father Olmeda.
Cortes and his men arrive, breathless. Moctezuma greets t
Welcome, Malinche, to the holy place. He leads them to a large convex stone with leather straps corners. It is covered with blood.
This is our sacrificial stone. He indicates a brazier with five still-beating hearts.
And here we make our offerings.
Great Moctezuma, I can contain myself no longer. I must tell you... We see Moctezuma's face as he listens, and Cortes' voice
Our Captain calmly stated our mission: to convert the natives to Christianity. He also explained the Trinity and other mysteries which we accept on faith. Cortes' voice fades up again:  67.
So that ours is the one true God. Moctezuma nods.
Malinche, I am sure your God is good to you. So are ours, to us. I o not ask you to forsake your beliefs. Please give to our people, and our Gods, the same respect. Cortes glances at the brazier -
Didn't you hear what I said?! This is an abomination!
(quietly, calmly) Not now, Captain.
These "Gods" are devils! As Cortes raises his voice to the Emperor, several Aztec as if to seize him. Moctezuma motions for them to desist.
Let us place our Virgin here and pee how your false Gods shrink from er! As Marina translates, Moctezuma shakes his head sadly, an for his guests to leave.

I_have committed a grave sacrilege in bringing you here. These Gods make the sun shine, the rain fall and the corn grow. I must now atone for exposing them to such blasphemy. He walks away, into one of two large temples. Cortes wants to pursue him, but Father Olmeda lays a calm the Captain's shoulder...
"No use to overturn the alter if the idol remains enthroned in the heart." Father Olmeda leads Cortes away.  68.
That night we pondered Cortes' blunder. Would Moctezuma see that we could not be their Gods if we defiled their Gods?
Clouds of incense roll toward the ceiling. Spectacular ta cover the walls. On the floor, beautiful gifts are laid o of palm leaf. Moctezuma and Cortes sip cold cocoa.

Despite Cortes' outburst, Moctezuma received us with great courtesy, toasting our Captain with frothy cocoa drinks. He asked jokingly to see the machines said to spew thunder and lightening. Cortes skirted questions of religion...

Except to ask, most politely, if we could construct a chapel in our own quarters. Soldiers remove a large animal skin from the wall. Father Olmeda stares at what is revealed: A small doorway, plastered over. Father Olmeda runs his hand along the plaster: fresh.
Fetch Cortes.

The plaster around the doorway is gone. Velasquez de Leon inserts his sword and pries off the cov It falls. Sandoval approaches with a burning torch and glances at C Cortes nods. Like a vision from some fairy tale: gold in nuggets and d grains, semi-precious stones (turquoise, jade, onyx, opal exquisite plates and metalwork combining these riches tog and piles of everything. This is El Dorado.

We later learned: this wealth represented 100 years of Aztec rule. When I saw it, I knew there was nothing to compare in all the world. The eyes of the Spaniards are wide with greed. Cortes' Pa rapid calculations in his notebook. Cortes is lost in reverie, fingering gold dust. Suddenly he realizes Father Olmeda's eyes are on him. He blinks - Looks up -
Am I a good Christian, Father?

Good Christians don't do this work. He says it gently, about Cortes...but his fatalistic tone it may apply equally to himself. Cortes lays the jewels down and leaves the room. After a moment, the others follow.
Touch nothing. Board it up as before, and put the alter in front. As the men move the large alter toward the door -
Eerie background music. AZTEC NOBLES watch: Spanish soldiers wager greedily with cards made from drum Other Spaniards stand guard.
For the next days, they watched us. The behavior of the Spanish gamblers seems crude, uncivil

The Mexicans, whose obsession with cleanliness extended to daily bathing and public latrines, were curious if our excrement, like that of the Gods, was gold. As the Soldier walks away, several Young Aztecs run into toilet to examine what has been left. They exit, holding their noses.

Royal entertainment: Dancers, spectacular foot-jugglers.. But the two leaders seem edgy: Moctezuma smiles at Cortes and nods. Cortes replies in the same way. Too formal. Long beat. Moctezuma glances to one side. Cortes follows the glance: The fierce and warlike Cuauhtemoc is cracking tiny nuts w teeth and eating them. Cortes exchanges looks with Sandoval and Velasquez De Leo is coming...
Cortes lying in bed beside Marina. Eyes open, worrying. S loud knock at the door. Velasquez De Leon enters, followe Cristobal, Alvarado, Sandoval.
Captain? I'm sorry to...
What is it?
A messenger just arrived from Vera Cruz. Aztecs there have killed 20 of our shipmates. Cortes nods. Stares. Looks around at the others.
We must act.
Quickly.
Decisively.
Yes. Tomorrow we must save ourselves... or die in the attempt. (long beat) This is what I propose...
Cortes and a dozen men cross the square to Moctezuma's pa
Tomorrow morning will seem the same as today. A group of us will go to Moctezuma's chambers. As always, we will be fully armed. After the first dozen, a second casually follows. Then a
For the first time, other soldiers will follow. We must hope they attract no particular notice.  72. The last two groups loiter outside Moctezuma's palace...
The Spaniards enter, and Moctezuma nods graciously.
Then, when we enter, I will -
Great Moctezuma, I must demand - Moctezuma stops him with a gesture. He proceeds playfully
Malinche, is this true that of the riches I give your King, he will receive only a fifth?
Yes, but -
And_you receive an equal fifth? Cortes nods. Moctezuma proceeds with mock outrage:
And the rest is divided among your men?
It's true. Moctezuma stares gravely at Cortes and then bursts out la
You're a very clever man! He continues to laugh. No one joins him. He realizes there is tension in the air. Nods gravely.
You have heard about 20 of your men?
Yes.
I_hear it too, with shame and sadness. I have come to think of you as my brother, and to show my eart has good will...  73. He motions and a gorgeous princess, DONA ANA, appears.
I_am giving you today my third daughter, to be one of your wives. For a moment Cortes is thrown off course, both by the act generosity and the luminous beauty of this girl.
She is very beautiful... Marina dutifully translates this...

But that does not change what happened. There have been too many accidents. Until those who killed my men can be brought here and questioned, you yourself must come with us, to our quarters. He watches Moctezuma's face as Marina translates. Bewilderment, then shock, then outrage. Moctezuma's eyes flash toward his GUARDS - Because they have their eyes lowered, they do not see him As his mouth opens, Velasquez de Leon and Cristobal appro swords drawn. There is nothing Moctezuma_ can do. He is trapped. He lowers his eyes. His body trembles with rage.
Go...as your prisoner?
As our guest.
Is this how my kindness is rewarded? (anger ) When did a great prince such as myself, ever leave his palace to stay with strangers?!
You will hold court there, as always. Everything will be the same. Moctezuma stares at Cortes.  74.
Even if I should consent to such a degradation, my subjects never would. I remain here.

Then let the barbarian die! Now! Beat. Moctezuma looks at Marina. Marina looks at Cortes: translate? He nods, and she translates. Moctezuma stares at Cortes. Expressionless, but thinking. Finally he smiles. And stands. Paradoxically, he seem str imperious... He gestures toward the door
Let _us go then to the palace of my father and see what destiny awaits.
Moctezuma walks, escorted, across the square to Axayacatl
Cortes warned that our victory was temporary. We would still have to fight the Aztecs, and the conflict would be savage, and soon. Moctezuma's posture is straight, proud, bewildering.
young Bernal Diaz sits making marks on an Aztec scroll us pencil. Cortes walks by. Stops. Looks. Looks again.

Making notes. So I can remember

No. So you can tell the world. (long beat) That is, if you live. He laughs and walks away. Young Diaz looks after him, then looks down again at his now he's looking at them in a different way...

We kept our word. Outwardly nothing changed except the location of Moctezuma's court. to Sandoval) Follow Cuauhtemoc and arrest him. Sandoval starts after Cuauhtemoc, motioning to SEVERAL SO accompany him. Cuauhtemoc is still visible down the long we see the Spaniards quickly closing in for the arrest. Cortes looks at Marina...hesitates...

According to Cortes, they said they were acting on Moctezuma's orders. The Aztecs claimed we misunderstood. As Mexican pedestrians look on in astonishment, Moctezuma a balcony in shackles. Cortes and Moctezuma play an Aztec dice game, throwing sm pellets and slabs across the room. The two men seem cheer relaxed, the best of friends.

Moctezuma was unchained after the burnings, and he was different. Was he hiding something? Waiting? He seemed to have a hidden faith that somehow his Gods would release him from this indignity. A brief pause in the game. We catch Moctezuma staring at look on his face is completely inscrutable.
Cortes and Marina walking, with Cristobal and Alvarado be The streets are crowded with Indians who keep glancing in direction, as if waiting for something.
We enjoyed the city. We relaxed. And every time we did, we saw something that chilled our hearts.
No, no, no. I don't think there is - or should be - any limit to the number of women a man can have. In Arabia - They stop. A noise. A procession approaching. The Aztecs around them start to weep.
What? What is it? The Spaniards group together, watching as: Six Children are borne through the streets. They are weep profusely. The Aztec pedestrians are weeping with equal abandon.
They believe the tears of the children bring rain, so the crops will grow.  79.
Then...this is theatre?
No. The children are sacrificed. All the Spaniards stare in disbelief.

My Gods and my people will rise.

(measured, a threat) Then I give my permission.
Cortes stares up at Huitzilopochtli, the fat Aztec war Go cheeks, terrible eyes, girdled with hissing snakes. Cortes extends his hand. An iron bar is placed in it

Make it clean. He leaps onto the idol and begins SMASHING it. This is no demolition. This is RAGE. FURY. MADNESS. At first others join in, but the pace and intensity of th assault distracts them. They stop and stare. At Father Olmeda's side, Velasquez de Leon shakes his hea
Yes. This goes beyond faith.
Perhaps...the slaughter in Cholula, burning those people alive... Does he feel some remorse?
No. This is about his greatness. Cortes' anger is both scary and awe-inspiring...
If he truly had faith, he would accept himself as a gift from God.
Spaniards filing into one large building, Aztecs into the

So it was that for a few days an Aztec temple and Christian church stood side by side, in peace. INTERCUT the two ceremonies: - Father Olmeda waving incense. - Aztecs waving incense as they lead a BEAUTIFUL BOY, 19, steps of the pyramid. He is surrounded by gorgeous YOUNG DIAZ (V.O. dy CONT'D) For the past year, Вў is beautiful boy had been fed the most exquisite food, tended to by the most beautiful girls, and lived a life of hedonistic joy. (MORE)

Today, HDEOKGEANEGDYith mushrooms, he would die so that the sun would continue to move in the heavens. He looks deliriously happy. Smiling, waving to the crowd. underneath, we HEAR the sound of his HEARTBEAT... - On the wall of the Catholic "church" hangs a deeply som of the baby Jesus surrounded by Joseph and Mary. - The Beautiful Boy walks onto the sacrificial stone and arms in exultation. The Aztecs cheer. - Father Olmeda stands at the pulpit. Behind him: a large Jesus' hands and feet are tightly bound to the cross. - Atop the sacrificial stone, the Beautiful Boy's hands a held by four Papas. A spear lances Jesus' chest: blo - The sacrificial knife cuts: blood flowing from the Beau chest. The rich red liquid flows off the stone into a cup

- Red wine in Father Olmeda's cup as he holds it to Corte - The palpitating heart is placed in the brazier. - The wafer is put into Cortes' mouth. - The Beautiful Boy's body is thrown down the side of the the Butchers who wait below. The Crowds cheer happily. - Communion continues: soberly feasting on the "body" of Moctezuma watches from the rear as Cortes walks up the ai He steps in Cortes' path - Cortes looks at him with surprise: how dare you interrupt
At least we kill and eat our enemies... even our selves...but not our Gods! He laughs derisively and walks away.

Through the window we see: the square filled with protest incited by a group of Papas. Drawing back inside:  83. Moctezuma sits surrounded by enraged Priests. His attitud posture tell us that his power has returned. On the mat in front of him is a pile of green wilted corn
The Gods are outraged. The People are in arms. Leave at once, or you will die.
My Lord, we would be pleased to go, but have no means. As you know, our ships were rotten and had to be sunk.
(smiles) But _- how lucky - new ships have arrived! He unfolds an Aztec scroll which shows several large vess
Spaniards! Cortes stares at the scroll.
Blessed be the Redeemer for his mercies. Can you tell, from this scroll, how many men have come?
Thirteen hundred.
And who is their leader?
A man named "Narvaez." Cortes stares at Moctezuma...
If you knows his name, then your men made contact with him. Moctezuma stares at Cortes, and then, very slowly, smiles
What sort of contact? Beat. Moctezuma is now confident, imperial again:
The God Smoking Mirror loves to play tricks on us all. INT. CORTES ROOM. NIGHT. A conference of the chief hidalgos.
Narvaez is sent by my cousin Velasquez to quell our mutiny. (off Cortes' look) But we are right to mutiny. History is on our side.
Screw history. Narvaez has fresh men, fresh horses -
And if Moctezuma is in contact with him, they must have made a deal.
Yes. Moctezuma has waited patiently, with great confidence, for the tide to shift. And now it has. (long beat) We have only one advantage. (off their looks) They both expect us to lose.
That's an advantage?!

We leave tonight. Alvarado will remain in charge of the garrison. will take 70 men to the sea. EXT. ROAD. NIGHT. Fast and forced march. Only it isn't a "march." The men are running. EXT. ROAD. DAY. Foot soldiers trotting, the five horses walking.
A_ foot soldier, tiring, pats the leg of a horseman, and places.  85.
Speed was our only ally, surprise our only weapon. Suddenly the company stops, peers into: a deep ravine. Th both directions: the ravine finally closes miles away...
Horses can be round in an hour, but those on foot will lose half a day. Cortes shakes his head; no good. He stares at the ravine: wide, no way to cross it...
Send the horses on. The others look at him skeptically. He addresses Sandoval
Go. Sandoval kicks his horse, and the other four ride after h
But how do we cross?
I don't know.
You don't - (know?! Are you crazy?!)
Some kind of bridge?
But what would we make it of? Again Cortes looks up and down the ravine.
Maybe the bridge is already here...
They stare at a huge sycamore tree five feet in diameter.
With swords? It would take half a day to cut it down...

Cortes shakes his head: Cristobal doesn't get it." Then Cristobal follows Cortes' gaze...up into the branche tree:  86. A hundred feet off the ground, the branches approach thos sister tree from the other side of the ravine. Cristobal gives Cortes a look: are you criminally insane?
Volunteers? None. Just as he expected. He starts to climb the tree.
You're not scared of heights?

No. Ts falling from heights I don't ike. MINUTES LATER. Cortes climbing quickly... Too quickly. He grabs a branch where wet leaves are resti Loses his grip - Plunges six feet, landing on another branch with terrific almost falling to his death. He lies there. Heaves a big sigh. Calls to those below:
Just a few ribs. Starts to climb again. As he does, the wind comes up, and the branches begin to Down below, Cristobal watches with Velasquez de Leon:
If he falls, we can return to Cuba.
To hell with Cuba!
Cristobal looks surprised at his vehemence.
Stop your whining. You have five women, a fortune in gold, and you're having the time of your life.  87.
True enough. (beat ) But I can complain if I want to.

looking up) Holy Mother of God... Cortes nears the top. Ties a rope to the tree he's in. The wind is strong. The pinnacle swaying back and forth.. approaching the sister tree, then pulling away... Approaching...pulling away... Cortes has to make his leap at precisely the right instan He's terrified. Prepares to leap, then stops himself. Rea
If you're scared, you'll fall. He takes a deep breath. Looks down at the others. Waves. Grins. This is not a moment for sanity. He looks back at the waving trees.

What the hell. Rope tied to his waist, he rocks with the tree, preparing Velasquez de Leon crosses himself. Cortes SCREAMS at the top of his lungs, LEAPS - Fails to catch his branch - Falls... Grabs another branch which breaks his fall, but can't hol Falls again and finally latches on, two hands gripping ti white, sick grimace on his face. He closes his eyes with relief: made it.
The rope is now strung from the top of the first tree to landed in the second, so that others can traverse the rav jumping. The last man, Cristobal, moves gingerly across..  88.

Hurry, the horses! Dust in the distance. 100 YARDS AWAY. MINUTES LATER. As the horses ride up, the foot soldiers wait directly ac where Sandoval left them. The sycamore trees sway in the Sandoval stops...stares...looks around dumfounded...
We flew. Sandoval nods. Of course.
Let's go. The horses walk, the men trot.
Tents sitting in the rain.

We reached the sea in 23 hours and sent on Father Olmeda and Martin Lopez, posing as messengers bearing a letter of conciliation. We hoped to thus distract Narvaez from our purpose. The rain is savage. Most tents are dark, but one is well- Approaching the doorway... INT. CORTES' TENT. NIGHT. Cortes pacing anxiously, Sandoval enters, looking very worried.
A m-messenger, sir.
From Father Olmeda and -
No. From T-T-Tenoch -
If it's bad news, say it  89.

Alvarado believed the Mexicans were about to attack. He struck first during one of their festivals, and slaughtered them. The entire city is now counter-attacking our garrison. Cortes stares at him thoughtfully...
Perhaps this was Moctezuma's plan, with Narvaez. Divide and conquer.
(quite concerned) W-w-what are we going to do?
calm, almost amused: ) Well... I guess we better defeat Narvaez, don't you think? leans back, closes his eyes Wake me when Father Olmeda an Martin Lopez return.
Martin Lopez marking Xs on a map:
Sentry. Sentry. And Narvaez is here, on top of the cue.
His men?
Adventurers. They have little loyalty to him and great interest in you and your gol
How far is it? , MARTIN LOPEZ . Without rain, an hour's journey.
And now? They look out at the downpour: only fools would...
Miserable march through thick rain. No trotting now. Cort Cristobal, and Sandoval walk in front.
(to Sandoval) Yes. I had a cat once too... But it died.
That's too bad, I -
I strangled it.
Oh.
I had good reason. Cortes stops, falls to his knees.
What now?! Sandoval joins Cortes. Cristobal sees: The small cross erected when they left Cempoala.
How could we find this? In the dark, the rain? He kneels too. Sandoval speaks their thought:
Because Our Lord favors us.

The rain has almost stopped. From a distance, Cortes and at the size of the camp, the number of tents. It appears chance. Cortes motions with his head: let's go. INSIDE THE CAMP. A SENTRY turns to look the other away, and ten of Cortes' into camp. When the Sentry turns back, he sees two clusters of men w casually. Cortes waves to the Sentry and calls:
Saint Iago! Down with Cortes!  91. The Sentry waves to them -

head_text.subj: INSIDE A TENT ON TOP OF A CUE

text: NARVAEZ (42, swarthy, muscular) is making love to an Indi PULL BACK OUT of the tent, focus on: CORTES' GROUP. As they spot the light from Narvaez' tent, and stealthily the pyramid. Sandoval and four other men run up the steps other direction. Suddenly nearby voices call:

To arms! We're being attacked! Cortes and his men raise their muskets and fire. Other rifles go off simultaneously. Sandoval's group sprints up the cue. Narvaez's men rush from their tents, fumbling with their are quickly taken prisoner.
Cortes! Victory to Cortes! His men take up the chant, reloading their rifles and fir into the air -
Narvaez trying to untangle himself from his amorous lover for some kind of clothing -
From every side, Cortes' men are firing into the air. Meanwhile: fireflies are blinking in the distance. Narvaez's men hear the musket shots, see the fireflies...

Narvaez' men mistook the blinking fireflies for our muskets and thought we had somehow mustered a huge force. Cortes and Sandoval, from opposite sides, are climbing th to-hand combat. They reach the top as a silhouette in a nightshirt runs f gut into the darkness and is attacked from two sides. He ace -  92.
Santa Maria, help me! They have killed me and put out my eye!
V-victory! V-victory for Cortes! Narvaez is dead! Down below, Cortes' men take up the chant: "Narvaez is de echoes across the camp.
Cortes sits in an orange gown receiving homage from Narva He offers his hand imperiously for them to kiss.
Narvaez was not dead. His humiliation was completed in the morning when he saw our meager forces. Narvaez sits nearby. He is now wearing an eye patch.
Thank your evil luck for putting me into your power so easily.
I have much to be thankful for, but this is the least of my achievements. Cortes gives each of Narvaez' men a small sack. At_a mome one else is in hearing, Cortes explains to Sandoval:

The gold is to keep these mercenaries from having second thoughts. Nearby, two of Cortes' men - Villafana (a common soldier distinctive scar who we saw on the docks in Cuba) and his watch with barely concealed rage.
But our own men have received nothing, These gifts will -
Exactly. (to Villafana and Cohort) What sort of soldiers follow a man like Narvaez? Do they fight for glory or God? No. Only for gold.  93.
I am the same.

Good. You shall have the gold you dream of. (giving him _a_ small sack) Lots of it. And we shall use these (indicates Narvaez' men) cousins of ours to get it. A SOLDIER on horseback rides up furiously, hands Cortes a Sandoval watches as Cortes reads the message with grave c
Our garrison?
The Aztecs stopped their attack. why? He rises, conceals his concern, and announces cheerfully:
Men! Let us march to Tenochtitlan and show our recruits how much the Aztecs love us.

The expanded Spanish Army walking along a causeway. Like a neutron bomb landed: No Indians in sight. In the distance, a single canoe skims the water. Ominous. Cortes and Sandoval exchanged worried looks. Some of the bridges which connected other dikes have been Clear implication: the Spaniards will have to fight their

P-perhaps the last message we received was a trick? As they cross one of the bridges, a horse falls. The caravan stops. Cortes trots back to examine the animal. Leg broken, it w be destroyed. Botello, the exotic little man who was throwing tarot on mutters something. Cortes glowers in his direction:
What did you say?  94.
I don't care if you hate me. I speak the truth. This is a bad omen.
In a deserted city, you need a spastic horse to tell you something is wrong? Botello gestures derisively and retreats. Cortes stares at the horse.

Shoot it. The order carried out. Cortes looks anxiously toward Tenochtitlan. Silence... Cortes begins to fidget... He and Sandoval exc another look... Finally we hear a shot fired in reply. Cortes spurs his horse and they move on.

Cortes and his men enter. The square is empty except FOUR MEXICA, each standing in dripping blood. Cortes and company look at the Mexica with mounting horro realize: The reason they drip blood is because they are wearing th slaughtered men. Cortes turns to Marina:
This is intended to scare us?

No. It's one of their rituals. The Ceremony of the Flayed Men. Cortes nods. Stares again at the four men... Barely overcoming his horror, he kicks his horse and move Alvarado rushes out to meet him.  95.
How are your troops?
No food. No water. Moctezuma is approaching. Cortes dismounts and walks right past him. On Moctezuma's face: rage, then sadness, confusion; and a
Is this the reward I get for calling off my men and preventing the slaughter of yours?
You prefer to kill us slowly, cutting off food and water?
I_am helpless to change these things when I am your captive.
Aren't you the Great Moctezuma? Long beat. They stare at each other.
If you wish our markets reopened you must release my nephew Cuauhtemoc.
He hates all Spaniards.
He is married to my youngest daughter, he is in line for the throne, and he will obey the emperor. Cortes considers this, finally turns to De Leon:
Order it done. (stares at Moctezuma...) When I was gone, why did you save my men? (off Moctezuma's stare) You feared for your life?
The greatest honor for a warrior is to die in combat. May that be my fate.  96.
Then why?
Because you Cortes, are a most remarkable. ..being. It seems an unequivocal statement of admiration and awe.
I_wanted to make sure you came back. He smiles, with an ominous hint of triumph...
Alvarado talking as Cortes stares out the window.

...our spies said they were planning to attack, so I struck first... Cortes watches as Cuauhtemoc is released from the Spanish walks across the square. As Cuauhtemoc passes TWO WOMEN, they lower their eyes def They will not look at his face. Cortes frowns: what does this mean?
So you see? I had no choice.
(whirls) Choice?! This was their festival, during which they NEVER wage war!
I caught them by surprise -
They outnumber us a thousand to one! The one thing you were not to do was provoke their wrath!
Yes sir.
You are a great soldier, Alvarado, with the brain of a crustacean. When we return to battle, you will fight in the most precarious position.  97.
grins) Sounds good to me.
Get out of here! Alvarado leaves. Cortes stares after him. Then he looks again out the wind Cuauhtemoc no longer visible. Just a few Aztecs...
I should have left Velasquez de Leon in charge. We think he's talking to an empty room.
He's the only man I have who's not a child. Marina approaches him. At her touch, his speech becomes g affectionate.
But the children are so simple. (glance after Alvarado) One must never blame them for being themselves.
What worries you?
(scornful) Worried? (stops... thinks...) That I've led them all to slaughter.
Diaz, the Young Soldier who planted the orange pips, lies his bedroll, fully armed. His face peaceful, almost innoc

Even when this campaign was over, I always slept on the floor, in my clothes. I grew used to it, and for ears after I never lay down ina ed unless there was a woman in it. A commotion nearby; soldiers run and shout. Diaz does not  98. A flaming arrow pierces the air and lands on Young Diaz' bursts into flames. He leaps up and stamps it out. Around him, other soldiers jump to arms -
As Cortes and Marina approach, Moctezuma stands watching and stroking his python...
It is my shame I am here with you and not there, leading my people.
Who is the warrior who leads them?
(knowing the answer) Where? Cortes points to a dynamic Chieftain exhorting his troops
You don't recognize my nephew Cuauhtemoc, who you just released?!
You told me he would open the markets.
He has. To our people.
You said he would obey the emperor.
He_ does. As of now, he is the emperor. Enraged, Cortes stalks out of the room -
Spaniards burst out of Axayacatl's palace and are quickly by TZILACATZIN, a giant Aztec slingshot artist, and other
Moctezuma's gentle manners had not prepared us for this battle. (MORE)
Slow to 9HAS6CONReDAztecs were even more difficult to pacify.
Flaming arrows, Indians leaping through windows, smoke so can hardly see. Guns fire, swords slice the air; a vision
They suffered great casualties, but when we sued for peace, they told us 25,000 of their number could die for every Spaniard and they would be content.
Father Olmeda with Moctezuma. DIAZ (V.O. Their love of death terrified us so we appealed to Moctezuma to end the bloodshed.
I_ desire only to die.
(gently) But must all your people, and ours, die with you? Moctezuma stares at him.
Allow us to leave in peace, and we will never return. Long beat. Moctezuma stares at Father Olmeda.
I_understand more than you think. Father Olmeda is about to question this enigmatic reply w Moctezuma rises slowly to his feet.

The battle rages. Cortes and Marina watch:  100. Moctezuma walks onto a rooftop, dressed in his official r loin cloth, mantle embroidered with feathers, gold decora turquoise ear plugs, a jade ornament piercing both nostri rock crystal tube piercing his lower lip. His face is bri painted. The effect is bizarre but quite beautiful) He's surrounded and protected by Spaniards. The Aztecs stop fighting, but their attitude toward Mocte changed: it's still respectful, but for the first time th directly at his face.
People, my people who I love, brave people, why are you fighting? To save me? I_am not a prisoner. I am already dead. Marina translating for Cortes...
Already..."dead?"
Do you want to drive away the strangers? That is not necessary. If you let them go, the strangers will leave and never return. This is their word. They give their word. Should we not believe them?
What is he doing? What's he saying?

Have not the strangers always been honest and true? Go home, then, Take the word of these strangers and lay down your arms. Listen please. Listen to your emperor. He stops. His eyes search the crowd and find Cuauhtemoc.
He nods to Cuauhtemoc. Cortes sees it.
I am the Emperor now! Listen to me! This man is a coward! A rising swell of anger as other Aztecs shout similar ins is enraged at this carefully staged piece of theatre.  101.

(to Cortes) They are calling him a eunuch, an old woman, a sodomite for the white men. Cuauhtemoc fires an arrow at Moctezuma. Barely misses. Ot shoot arrows, throw stones, and hurl insults - Moctezuma stands proudly: accepting, even welcoming, the The Spaniards Guards, taken by surprise, rush to protect Moctezuma is hit on the chest by two stones - The giant Tzilacatzin fires his slingshot... And hits Moctezuma on the head. He drops -

Spanish Guards hurriedly cover him up and carry him insid INT. PALACE. DAY. As Moctezuma is carried in, he is brought past a glaring Moctezuma looks up at him with a wan smile of triumph. He is then carried into the adjoining room. Cortes glares after him with homicidal fury, then follows the other room. The door closes slowly, ominously.. Hold on the door. In the b.g., we HEAR THE BATTLE RAGING.
SAME DOOR, later. (BATTLE SFX, under.) Sandoval exits, an those who are waiting: SANDOVAL ; He's refusing all medical treatment.
SAME DOOR, later. (BATTLE, under.) Velasquez De Leon exit
He's refusing all food.
SAME DOOR, later. Cortes' Page emerges, downcast.
Moctezuma is dead Others move forward: "What happened?", "What did he die o  102.
He refused the sacraments.
Cortes and Father Olmeda hover near Moctezuma's wheezing
Cortes was with him to the end.
I beg you again, Great Speaker. (indicating Olmeda) Before your soul is damned -

No. My Gods have forsaken me, but I will not forsake them. Besides... He indicates Father Olmeda, who at the moment is examinin evident greed a beautiful gold necklace... When Cortes turns back, Moctezuma gives him his hand:
Malinche... My daughters, sweet and fiery, are here with you. Will you protect them?

(touched) Of course. (hesitates, can't resist asking: ) And you, can you tell me... They sa you were once a great warrior to f Moctezuma's nod Why did you never fight us? Moctezuma smiles as if to say: Don't you know??

If_ you were a God, I dared not, If you were what you say, ambassador toa great King: What kind of King would I be if TI made war on an ambassador? (breathing more heavily...) Besides, we Mexica fight wars to gain captives. (gestures) Here in Tenochtitlan, are you not already our prisoner? Cortes stares at him, stunned...  103. Moctezuma smiles wanly... Cortes realizing suddenly: has Moctezuma_ already defeate Moctezuma's breath getting shorter and shorter... ANOTHER ANGLE. MOMENTS OR MINUTES LATER. The Page watches as: Cortes closes Moctezuma's eyes. INT. THE NEXT ROOM. As Cortes' Page finishes this story.
Is that really what happened?
Of course

But...when he left here, Cortes seemed enraged at Moctezuma...? Cortes' Page stares at Young Bernal Diaz with a peculiar and we realize: the Page's story may be a lie. Their attention is diverted by the sound of the raging ba

At a barricaded doorway, soldiers are firing, reloading, again without aiming their shotguns and crossbows: the In thickly massed the Spaniards can't miss. Botello the Soothsayer stands waiting as Cortes paces the listening to the anxious report of:
-handful of corn per day: Without food and clean water, we'll never last the week.
(turns to Botello) You were right about the horse's death.
As always.
If I seek your counsel, am I no better than Moctezuma, whose world is cursed by superstition?  104.
(snide) A pretty question, sir. Shall I consult the stars for an answer?
(irritable) What is your augury now? For us?
Leave tomorrow night or die. Cortes nods thoughtfully and giances across the room, whe CARPENTERS are building some kind of contraption...
(supporting Botello) The Indians are still unprepared for night battle, so perhaps -
It's not military tactics; it's fate.
(growls) Fate is something we cause, not submit to. Father Olmeda arches an eyebrow at Cortes...
With God's mercy, of course.
Of course.

Battle raging. The front doors swing open, and FOUR MEXICAN PRINCES carr wrapped in turquoise cloth. The battle stops. The body is borne with great solemnity. Indian drums roll Soldiers on both sides stand silently in tribute. Even those Aztecs who cursed and threw stones now give Mo respect: let us forget failings and honor the dead.
Some say they gave Moctezuma's body royal honors; (MORE)
others BIAZHEQNGURDed him into a canal like carrion. Either way, they claim we killed him with a sword thrust up his rectum. Moctezuma's body disappears slowly around a corner...
The huge room where Moctezuma once held court is now the command room: Cortes and the other Hidalgos are diagrammi their departure. A Messenger is given final instructions, departs...

We had to flee. To camouflage our true intentions, we sent a message asking Cuauhtemoc for peace. Cortes' Page opens the door, and fifty Soldiers rush in. room is a pile: all the treasure the Spaniards have accum Soldiers dig greedily through these riches.

In all, it is worth 700,000 pesos! Cortes says: Take what you can. But remember: he goes safest at night who travels lightest. The men scarcely hear him; they're stuffing their shirts gold ingots. Across the room, the war council continues:
But Cortes wants me in the most precarious place, which is the rear.
Then I must fight there too. (to Alvarado) With due respect: we cannot survive another error in judgement... Alvarado turns toward Cortes and smiles with defiant char
Well? You're the Captain of the Captains. Cortes lowers his eyes and says sadly to Velasquez de Leo
We gratefully accept your offer
The men pack their bags and prepare for battle.

Two hours to departure. Two hours... Alvarado's warming up like a boxer: shoving the wall, gru psyching himself up... gristobal holds hands with two of his WIVES as two others eet. Sandoval tests the blade of his sword. Velasquez De Leon sits in a corner. Cervantes (the blond Cortes found long ago sleeping on his watch) walks past -
Hey! You! Cervantes!
Sir?
I have no one to drink with me. Will you -

(big grin) Shouldn't be a problem, sir. Velasquez de Leon hands Cervantes his bota (leather wineb Cervantes hoists it and sprays a stream into his mouth. O into his mouth; he spills some onto his armor...
The wine is Castilian. I've been nursing it the whole trip... Velasquez de Leon retrieves the bota and drinks himself. Lowers the bag...looks at Cervantes...
Are you in the rear?

Tonight's battle?! No sir. To be honest, I'm something of a coward, and I want to get out of here as quick as I can! Cervantes glances at the wine, hoping for another drink Velasquez de Leon hands him the bag.  107.
Could you carry this for me? You'll have a better chance of getting it through.

No problem, sir. No problem at all. And I promise I will not touch another drop. On my honor! He bows obsequiously, and saunters away with the bota... Velasquez de Leon stares. His face - placid on the surfac sad underneath that we can't bear to look at it. We glide to where Villafana and his Cohort, who complaine Narvaez' men received gold, are whispering conspiratorial
On this night, most of us knew we could only survive united. But in the whole campaign we never took a step forward without being sabotaged from the rear. We're now close enough to overhear
...we'll only reach Cuba if Cortes dies.
You wouldn't strike at him? Villafana shakes his head.
Even in battle?
Especially in battle. But in battle sometimes a man's virtues do him in... His Cohort is puzzled. As Villafana leans forward to expl

Cortes sleeping, Marina gently rubbing his head. She stops, looks at him. He's spread out on the bed, shirt open, Indian feathers s around as if having been incorporated in their love-makin Something momentous in her stoic face...  108. She undoes her huipil and we see her rounded belly: five along, but very large... Slowly, solemnly, she ties his shirt-tail to the tail of She places his sleeping hand over the knot. Puts her own hand over his. (From this Aztec ritual comes "tie the knot.") Sandoval knocks, sticks his head in.
Twenty minutes to midnight Marina nods. While the unwitting "groom" slept through th "ceremony," the "bride's" face streams with tears.
The doors swing silently open.

This was to be the most famous battle in our campaign. It came to be called "noche triste," the sad night. Two Spaniards exit, look around - The Square totally deserted. The Two Men motion, and 40 more emerge, carrying an enorm (the structure we saw being constructed)

We chose the shortest causeway. The bridges had been removed, so we built a mobile one to carry from one section to the next. The platform is followed by foot soldiers, cavalry, women porters, the Tlascalan allies, and finally the rear guard Velasquez de Leon and Alvarado.
It was dark. A fine mist obscured and muffled our departure. They enter the dike.

By some miracle, or by ineptitude, the Aztecs had posted no guards. The portable bridge is put in place and they start across  109. The land seems such a short distance away... Cortes stares, hoping: can they really escape without a b On the shore: AN AZTEC WOMAN, fetching water from the lak She sees them. Stands. Whistles. A beat, then answering whistles. And more. Like menacing birds - The Spaniards race across the portable bridge - Pirogues (the Mexican canoes) stream toward them.
